stem: The nurse is caring for a patient receiving mechanical ventilation. Which of the following nursing interventions are MOST important to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)? Select all that apply.

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees.
Perform regular oral care with chlorhexidine.
Ensure proper hand hygiene before and after patient contact.
Assess endotracheal tube cuff pressure regularly.

itemContext.sbar: Situation: Robert Miller, a 68-year-old male, is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to acute respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia. Background: Mr. Miller was admitted three days ago with a productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. He has a history of COPD and hypertension. Assessment: At 0700, his vital signs are: HR 110, BP 150/90, RR 16 (ventilator settings: FiO2 40%, PEEP 5 cm H2O, Tidal Volume 500 mL), SpO2 92%. He is on continuous sedation with propofol. Lung sounds reveal coarse crackles bilaterally. ETCO2 is 38 mmHg. Current medications include vancomycin and azithromycin. Recommendation: Please assess for signs of VAP and continue vigilant respiratory care. At 0800, note increased secretions and decreased oxygen saturation to 89%. Consider suctioning and potential changes in ventilator settings. Assess sedation level per RASS scale.

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees reduces the risk of aspiration, a major risk factor for VAP. Oral care with chlorhexidine reduces oral bacterial colonization, decreasing the risk of lower respiratory tract infection. Suctioning removes accumulated secretions, preventing bacterial pooling and colonization. Hand hygiene prevents the transmission of pathogens. Maintaining appropriate endotracheal tube cuff pressure (20-30 cm H2O) prevents leakage of contaminated secretions into the lower airway. Clinical Pearl: VAP significantly increases morbidity and mortality in mechanically ventilated patients.
rationale.incorrect: Routine antibiotic prophylaxis promotes antibiotic resistance and is not a standard VAP prevention strategy. Repositioning prevents pressure ulcers but does not directly prevent VAP. Increasing FiO2 to 100% can cause oxygen toxicity and does not prevent VAP. Instilling normal saline before suctioning can push bacteria deeper into the lungs and is not recommended. Question Trap: Some options are general nursing interventions, but the question asks specifically about VAP prevention.
clinicalPearls: VAP is a significant complication of mechanical ventilation, increasing morbidity and mortality.
Adherence to VAP prevention bundles is crucial for reducing the incidence of VAP.
Continuous aspiration of subglottic secretions (CASS) is another important intervention to prevent VAP in high-risk patients.

questionTrap.trap: Several options seem like standard nursing care, but the question focuses on VAP prevention specifically.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the pathophysiology of VAP and which interventions directly address the mechanisms leading to its development (e.g., aspiration, bacterial colonization).

mnemonic.title: VAP BUNDLE
mnemonic.expansion: V: Ventilator settings optimization; A: Aseptic technique; P: Positioning (HOB elevation); B: Breathing exercises and weaning assessment; U: Understanding and adherence to protocols; N: Nutrition; D: Daily sedation vacation; L: Lung hygiene (oral care, suctioning); E: Early mobility
